properties.title: Burlington Environmental, LLC
properties.description: Burlington Environmental LLC Georgetown The site was called “PSC Georgetown” in the past. In 1991, the Department of Ecology and EAP issued a permit to Burlington Environmental, LLC to treat and store hazardous waste at the site. The site is not currently in use, but toxic releases from past operations have contaminated soils and groundwater. A cleanup plan has been established. For information about the cleanup actions, please check out Department of Ecology webpage

properties.title: St. Mary under the bridge
1st Ave S and SW Michigan St
properties.description:
1st Ave S and SW Michigan St Seattle Department of Transportation is planning to make improvements at sites along the Duwamish River near the South Park and Georgetown neighborhoods. This is one of the sites, which is located at the intersection of 1st Ave S and SW Michigan St. Improvements include removing invasive species and planting new vegetation, and adding seating areas.

For more information, please checkout SDOT website.

properties.title: 8801 E Marginal Way South Site
properties.description:
8801 East Marginal Way South Site This site is located on the east bank of the Lower Duwamish Waterway in Tukwila. Contamination on the upland of this site is attributed to heavy industrial use since the 1920s. Soil and groundwater is contaminate with :
  • Petroleum hydrocarbons
  • Poly-aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs)
  • Volatile and semi volatile organic compounds (VOCs and SVOCs)
  • Polychlorinated biphenyls(PCBs)
  • Metals (primarily chromium, copper, lead, nickel and zinc)

In 2008, the Department of Ecology entered into a second legal agreement with the potentially liable parties to address the upland area of the site. In 2010, the potentially liable parties prepared a draft Remedial Investigatin report that summarizes past investigations, identifies contaminants of concern, areas of concern and data gaps. In 2011, a draft data gaps work plan was prepared and likely will be implemented in summer/fall 2011.

For more information, please check out Department of Ecology webpage.

properties.title: 1st Street and S River St
properties.description:
1st Ave S and S River St

Seattle Department of Transportation is planning to make improvements at sites along the Duwamish River near the South Park and Georgetown neighborhoods. This is one of the sites, which is located at the intersection of 1st Ave S and S River St. Improvements include removing invasive species and planting new vegetation, and adding seating areas.

Learn more on the SDOT website.

properties.title: Museum of Communication
properties.description: Open on Sundays.

properties.title: Boeing Isaacson Thompson Site
properties.description:
Boeing Isaacson Thompson Site The site is located at 8625-8811 E. Marginal Way S. in Tukwila, which is on the east bank of the Lower Duwamish Waterway. There are potential contamination in soil, groundwater, stormwater, and sediments.
The contaminants of concern in the soil are:
  • Arsenic, cadmium, chromium, lead, mercury, nickel, PCBs, petroleum hydrocarbons, zinc
The contaminants of concern in the groundwater are:
  • Arsenic, barium, chromium, lead
The contaminants of concern in the stormwater are:
  • Antimony, arsenic, lead, petroleum hydrocarbons
The chemicals of concern in sediments are:
  • Arsenic, benzopyrene, dibenzoanthracene, benzoperylene, phthalates, benzoic acid, benzyl alcohol, and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).



For more information, please check out Department of Ecology webpage.

properties.title: SSA Terminals
properties.description:
SSA Terminals Soundkeeper filed a lawsuit against SSA Terminals for violating the state-issued Industrial Stormwater General Permit, which regulates stormwater discharge from the facility. SSA Terminals has agreed to reduce pollution discharges by installing stormwater treatment plants to remove significant amounts of pollution from stormwater before its discharge to the Duwamish River.

For more information please check out the following article:
    Defending the Duwamish River: Puget Soundkeeper settles citizen action against SSA Terminals.

properties: Pigeon Point Restoration: planting native vegetation, remove invasive species
properties.description:
West Duwamish Greenbelt / Pigeon Point

SW Genesee St & 20th Ave SW
Seattle, 98106

RESTORE OUR RIVER!

The West Duwamish Greenbelt is a vital part of the Duwamish River watershed because of the crucial habitat and the pollution-fighting power the forest provides.

EarthCorps and Nature Consortium are joining forces again for the Annual Duwamish Alive Earth Day event at the West Duwamish Greenbelt/Pigeon Point Park. Join us, the Green Seattle Partnership and a host of partners and volunteers as we continue to restore the largest contiguous greenbelt in Seattle.

TO SIGN UP or for more information: email volunteer@naturec.org

Contact:
Lizzie Zemke, Nature Consortium
Email: lizzie@naturec.org
Phone: 206.923.0853

properties.title: Rainier Petroleum
properties.description:
Rainier Petroleum Corporation Rainier Petroleum’s facility in Pier 15 receives and stores shipment of petroleum products. Stomwater discharge in the area was highly polluted. With an industrial stormwater discharge permit, Rainier Petroleum failed to sample the runoff from their site for many years. The facility is now responsible for sampling twice/quarter and updating its stormwater pollution prevention plant to comply with the permit after a lawsuit brought up by the Puget Soundkeeper.

For more information please check out the following articles:
  • Rainier Petroleum must finally comply with the Clean Water Act
  • Rainier Petroleum must finally comply with the Clean Water Act
  • Puget Soundkeeper Citizen Lawsuits

properties.title: South Park Water Quality Facility
properties.description:
South Park Water Quality Facility

The South Park Water Quality Facility would help to protect the Duwamish River from polluted stormwater runoff.

The Integrated Plan includes a project to protect the Duwamish River from polluted runoff by building a stormwater treatment facility in South Park, where 7th Avenue South meets the river.

The project will have:

  • Underground equipment
  • Above-ground structures including a small electrical controls building and a concrete structure, about 12 feet tall, 50 feet wide and 110 feet long
  • Security fencing and lighting
  • Controls that allow staff to operate the facility remotely, reducing how often staff would need to visit it for maintenance

What’s Next?

SPU is in the process of evaluating stormwater treatment technologies for the facility. The analysis is expected to be complete in 2014. The expected project schedule would include:

2015-2018 Option Analysis and Pilot Testing
2018-2020 Design
2026 Construction Completed

To ask questions or let us know what you think, contact the project manager:

Sheila Harrison
sheila.harrison@seattle.gov
(206) 684-5899

For latest update please checkout Seattle Public Utilities webpage.

rowing
properties.description:
Duwamish Rowing Club

Making Some Amazing Memories!

Hi my name is Jonnie Suggs, and I am a member of the duwamish rowing team. The reason I used this picture is because I think it is one of the best pictures that was taken of our team, and I just really enjoy the sunset.

My name is James Suggs, I started rowing in 2010. I got into rowing by my mother, she introduced me to Michael Merta who then invited my sisters and I to start rowing. We were the first rowers on the team. Every year I got better and better at rowing, and I became more competitive. Over time our crew started growing and more people started joining. We started to go to rowing regattas, and by 2016 we had a pretty much had a full team.

skatepark
properties.description:
Skatepark Renewal

Goal

To keep the Skatepark clean and to make sure people are able to feel safe there when they visit. Keep it healthy for the community and the environment as well.

Status

Skate Park maintained by River City Skate Park organization. Site owned by SeaMar. 16 trees planted here as part of Duwamish Opportunity Fund.

Challenges

  • A lot of people go there to do drugs sometimes.
  • People have found uncapped needles which are dangerous either way.
  • Lot's of trash found everywhere.
  • Alley was also blocked off by thorn bushes.

Progress Detail

What the DRCC(Duwmaish River Clean-UP Coalition) did was brought more awareness to the Skatepark. They icked up a lot of trash in the area. They also safely and properly disposed of any needles used for drugs into safe containers provided by the Seattle Health Department. The Drcc also cut down and moved all the thorn bushes blocking out the alley.

properties.name: Restore the Duwamish Shoreline Challenge
properties.description:
Restore the Duwamish Shoreline Challenge
12770 Gateway Dr.
Tukwilla, WA 98168


Join volunteers all along the Duwamish River today as part of the larger Duwamish Alive! Celebration to help restore this important waterway in the Tukwila/South Seattle community.  At this location, we'll focus on removing invasive weeds, mulching and planting native plants.

Inspired by the efforts of the BECU employees who independently began restoration work on over 10,000 square feet of shoreline along the Duwamish River, and through a partnership with Forterra and the City of Tukwila, BECU is issuing a friendly challenge to other businesses along the river to join in restoring the shoreline habitat. Local businesses can participate by donating money, volunteer labor, or both.

Much of the banks of the Duwamish River are overgrown with invasive plants such as Himalayan blackberry that have choked out native vegetation. These invasive species are destroying vital habitat for salmon and other native wildlife, and make it more difficult for Tukwila’s workers and residents to enjoy the river.

Through the Restore the Duwamish Shoreline Challenge, we aim to unite Tukwila’s business community for this local environmental cause. There will be regularly scheduled events that will ultimately restore 150,000 square feet of riverbank along almost 1.5 miles of the Duwamish River.

How You Can Get Involved:
  • Sponsor a section of the river.  Funding is needed to purchase restoration materials, recruit and support volunteers, and maintain newly planted shoreline areas. Challenge sponsors will also receive recognition at our launch event and will be featured in publicity materials.
  • Organize a team of volunteers to help with restoration projects. Volunteer leaders can receive special training and help their workplace get involved.
  • Grant access. Much of the shoreline we hope to restore is on private property. Granting permission for Challenge participants to work on your property is a simple, but crucial step for our success.
  • Help get the word out.  Help others learn about the Challenge by putting up fliers, and by informing clients, customers, and colleagues.
  • Join a volunteer event. check our Events Calendar to find the next volunteer restoration event at the Duwamish.

To volunteer or join the challenge, please contact:

Hayes Swinney, Forterra   
Email: hswinney@forterra.org
Phone: 206-905-6909

Sponsors

properties.name: Herring's House
properties.description:
Herring's House
Herring’s House is a 15.5 acre location was built in 1999 primarily as habitat for juvenile Chinook salmon.  The site is built around a constructed intertidal estuary connected to the Duwamish River. The park features a picnic area, parking area, 3 viewpoints of the Duwamish River and the estuary and trails through the woodland buffers that surround the estuary.


To Volunteer:

Phil Renfrow, Volunteer Coordinator
Seattle Parks and Recreation

Phone: (206) 423-1677
properties.title: Herrings House

properties.name: Roxhill Bog
properties.description:
Roxhill Bog

2850 SW Roxbury St.
Seattle, WA 98126

At the headwaters of Longfellow Creek, this wetland acts as an essential water filter for a 3.5-mile long waterway that’s home to coho salmon, ensatina salamanders, and red foxes feeding downstream. The creek drains a 2000-acre watershed and is one of the few year round free-flowing creeks in Seattle.  As the drainage basin for sixty surrounding acres, Roxhill Bog collects sediments and pollutants from rain and storm water run off. Plants absorb some pollutants while the spongy peat soil helps filter sediments, essential for providing healthy water quality.  Longfellow Creek is one of Seattle's few salmon spawning creeks.


Contact: Scott Blackstone
Volunteer Coordinator, Friends of Roxhill Bog
Email:  scottie1039@aol.com
Phone: 206- 484-3247
properties.title: roxhill-bog

properties.name: T-107
properties.description:
T-107

T-107 is an important archaeological, cultural and historical site that sits on the shores of the original Duwamish River. Also known as Terminal 107, this portion of the riverbank was originally the construction site for a marine terminal. In 1977, artifacts were found during the development process, which halted all construction. The tribe and the community fought to preserve the area, and today it now stands as a wildlife habitat and a lovely public access site that overlooks the only original bends in the river. T-107 is an important habitat node, or oasis, where returning salmon and other wildlife can rest, feed and escape from predators… we want to keep it this way, and make it even better by joining a volunteer habitat restoration party!
properties.title: T107

properties.name: LaFarge Asphalt - criminal pollution site
properties.description:
An eight-year investigation at the Lafarge North America cement plant was conducted where divers snuck water monitoring equipment into the drain of the cement plant to monitor chemical waste dumping. The investigation ended with a $300,000 settlement with the Environmental Protection Agency and no criminal prosecution. Photo: Joshua Trujillo / Seattlepi.com

Read more in the Seattle PI.

properties.title: happytrail
properties.description:
Scary Trail no more!

The youth of South Park hit the trail with a major overhaul. Watch the video above for a rundown.

Together, we:

Transformed the space

  • Removed 200 cubic yards of debris and invasive plants.
  • Planted over 200 native plants.
  • Replaced 100 cubic yards of topsoil and 50 cubic yards of mulch.
  • Laid 92 burlap bags
  • Hauled out 4 1/2 giant dump truck loads of waste to the city transfer station.

Built connections to our neighborhood

  • The beautiful new yarn flowers on the fence were made possible by 15 Latina senior women in South Park who partnered with us and spent 100+ hours crocheting and knitting.
  • We unearthed a historical treasure that had been buried and forgotten. An old brick sidewalk that once connected the old neighborhoods together, in an area used to known as "Catholic Hill." Things changed in 1967, when the freeway was constructed and divided the neighborhoods.

properties.title: Groundwater contamination - Philip Services Corporation
properties.description:
Groundwater contamination originating from the property owned by 
Philip Services Corporation (“PSC”) on Lucile Street near Airport Way 
has been a persistent issue in Georgetown.  Over the years since the 
1940’s, underground storage tanks at the property corroded and al-
lowed chemicals to leak into the soil and groundwater.  Eventually the 
tanks were removed an underground barrier, or “slurry wall,” was 
constructed around most of PSC’s property in order to prevent further 
migration of the contaminants. In 2010, a Cleanup Action Plan (CAP) 
was finalized with public comment and input on behalf of the 
Georgetown Community Council provided by Environment Interna-
tional, a consulting firm experienced in contaminated site cleanups. 
The Department of Ecology is close to releasing two milestone docu-
ments that are key to the cleanup of contaminated soil and groundwa-
ter at the PSC site.  One is a review of the overall progress in the five 
years since the CAP was finalized, and the other is more specific, relat-
ed to the particular technology selected to remove a certain hard-
to
-
treat contaminant (1,4-dioxane) from the areas where it is found at con-
centrations of concern. 
The progress report is called a Periodic Review, and examines how 
well the cleanup action has performed so far, makes sure that human 
health and the environment are being adequately protected given the 
current progress, and identifies a few actions for improvement.  A Peri-
odic Review will happen every five years until the site has reached its 
cleanup goals. 
In the Periodic Review, Ecology reports that the cleanup is proceeding 
as expected.  However, new information is available about some of the 
chemicals being addressed in the cleanup, and Ecology is asking PSC 
to re-calculate potential soil and groundwater cleanup levels based on 
the new information, to compare them with the cleanup levels from the 
2010 CAP. 
The primary chemical that the cleanup has not yet effectively ad-
dressed is 1,4-dioxane in groundwater.  The CAP originally specified 
that the affected groundwater should be pumped out from a single 
location, treated with an “oxidant” (a chemical that breaks down the 
1,4-dioxane), and discharged to the sewer.  Today, it appears that 
there are multiple hot spots of contamination, and Ecology believes 
that a more effective method would be to inject the oxidant directly 
into the ground in several locations.  A study is also underway to find 
out whether there are bacteria that can help break down even more of 
the contamination.  Because this plan is different than the plan in the 
2010 CAP, the CAP needs an amendment. 
Public comment periods will be held for 30 days for each of these doc-
uments, once they are released.
Local residents will be notified by a 
mailer. You can learn more about the history of the site and status of 
the cleanup on these web pages: 
https://fortress.wa.gov/ecy/gsp/Sitepage.aspx?csid=2622 
www.georgetownneighborhood.com/phillip_services/index.html

properties.title: Yellow brick road toward the Emerald City
rose-end
properties.description:
Rose Street End

Goal

Spectacular overlook for the new South Park Bridge and connection the residential area through a riverfront trail that connects to the future South Park Plaza. Public art, river restoration, way-finding and picnicking.

Status

  • Land owned by King County

Challenges

  • Multiple jurisdictions own the property
  • Need to sort out ownership before delving into design

Next Steps

  • King County and City of Seattle to negotiate land transfer

properties.title: Joint Training Facility Campus
properties.description:
Joint Training Facility Campus This is one of the five Myers parcels the City of Seattle is planning to sell, which raises environmental concerns since the land is situated in the Hamm Creek drainage area and feeds into the Duwamish. An online petition has created to stop the sale.
The property is currently under review for reuse or disposition. This parcel has been identified by the Seattle Fire Department and Seattle Public Utilities as a potential expansion of the JTF.

For more information please check out the following articles:
  • Should Seattle sell off rare open space
  • Stop the City of Settle sale of Myers Parcels Petition

properties.title: Parcel D
properties.description:
Parcel D This is one of the five Myers parcels the City of Seattle is planning to sell, which raises environmental concerns since the land is situated in the Hamm Creek drainage area and feeds into the Duwamish. An online petition has created to stop the sale.
The property is currently under review for reuse or disposition. The property has not been identified for a potential future City use, although, with the existing wetlands and steep slopes, it will be preserved either under continued City ownership or under private ownership. An excess property notice has been sent to residents located within a 1,000-foot radius of the site.

For more information please check out the following articles:
  • Should Seattle sell off rare open space
  • Stop the City of Settle sale of Myers Parcels Petition

properties.title: marra
properties.description:
Marra Farm

Goal

Increase Marra farms Local and community involvement. Create a safer and cleaner enviroment for youth. Marra farm has rich history of the of the community aroud it.

Challenges

Marra Farm has had a history of drug use and homelessness. As well as the most recent issue of cost and liability of community input wanting to change terrain.

Status

As of most recent Marra farm has come under discussion of what to build and a higher community input and involvement. Right now being used by Concord Elementary School and local gardeners. While the enevitable spring arrives the replanting of the food will increase community involvement.

Progress Detail

Community involvement fluxiates less crime usually increases community involved in the marra Farm

Challenges and Bariers

Solutions on how to restore the Marra Farm will be plentyful, so choosing multiple or even a few would be difficult. Not to mention satisfying everyone would be very difficult

Next step

Figure out the next step to restoring the marra farm. I will survey local homeowners near Marra Farm. If possible take input from Mr.Marra. Come up with a solution and testing out said solution for Marra Farm.

properties.Title: George Lee / The Duwamish Lighthouse / Jack Block Park
properties.Description:
2130 Harbor Avenue SW | Seattle, WA, 98126

The Duwamish Lighthouse responds to real-time water quality data and translates it into light, in the form of our own breathing: Steady and relaxed is a cleaner river, fast and spasmodic is a polluted river. To learn more, and interact with the Lighthouse, go to www.duwamishrevealed.com/duwamishlighthouse

The Duwamish Lighthouse can be found on an old concrete pier along the shoreline at Jack Block Park, and is visible from the public pier.

Funded by Seattle Public Utilities and Seattle Office of Arts & Culture 1% for Art Funds.

properties.title: south-park-community-center
properties.description:
South Park Community Center

Goal

Remake the playgorund area so kids can be more excited on going to the park and having fun. Also, add football marks to the field so it can be a football field for the South Park Soldiers. remove the Sand-Pit becacause it hasn't been used correctly. Like people pee and poop in it, no one really plays in it, and too many bugs in it. One other thing is to add huge lights facing the field so it can be more visible when the sun sets (safety).

Status

Seattle Parks and Recreatiob designing a new playround in 2016-- Community Desire to include the fields

Progress Detail

South Park Green Space Committee writing a parks challenge grant-- Seattle Parks foundation talking with potential funders

Challenges and Barriers

City wide athletics schedules the fields-- Improved fields are over scheduled, often by outside groups, neighbors loose access.

Next Steps

Modify scheduling practices to be more inclusive to the neighbirhood-- Submit Grant- 3.31.16

Make South Park an amazing Community!

properties.title: 5th Ave S and S Fontanelle St
properties.description:
5th Ave S and S Fontanelle St Seattle Department of Transportation is planning to make improvements at sites along the Duwamish River near the South Park and Georgetown neighborhoods. This is one of the sites, which is located at the intersection of 5th Ave S and S Fontanelle St. Improvements include removing invasive species and planting new vegetation, and adding seating areas.

For more information, please checkout SDOT website.
